children.text: The Raven
by Edgar Allan Poe
Once upon a midnight dreary, while I pondered, weak and weary,
Over many a quaint and curious volume of forgotten lore—
While I nodded, nearly napping, suddenly there came a tapping,
As of some one gently rapping, rapping at my chamber door.
“’Tis some visitor,” I muttered, “tapping at my chamber door—
Only this and nothing more.”
Ah, distinctly I remember it was in the bleak December;
And each separate dying ember wrought its ghost upon the floor.
Eagerly I wished the morrow;—vainly I had sought to borrow
From my books surcease of sorrow—sorrow for the lost Lenore—
For the rare and radiant maiden whom the angels name Lenore—
Nameless here for evermore.
And the silken, sad, uncertain rustling of each purple curtain
Thrilled me—filled me with fantastic terrors never felt before;
So that now, to still the beating of my heart, I stood repeating
“’Tis some visitor entreating entrance at my chamber door—
Some late visitor entreating entrance at my chamber door;—
This it is and nothing more.”
Presently my soul grew stronger; hesitating then no longer,
“Sir,” said I, “or Madam, truly your forgiveness I implore;
But the fact is I was napping, and so gently you came rapping,
And so faintly you came tapping, tapping at my chamber door,
That I scarce was sure I heard you”—here I opened wide the door;—
Darkness there and nothing more.
Deep into that darkness peering, long I stood there wondering, fearing,
Doubting, dreaming dreams no mortal ever dared to dream before;
But the silence was unbroken, and the stillness gave no token,
And the only word there spoken was the whispered word, “Lenore?”
This I whispered, and an echo murmured back the word, “Lenore!”—
Merely this and nothing more.
Back into the chamber turning, all my soul within me burning,
Soon again I heard a tapping somewhat louder than before.
“Surely,” said I, “surely that is something at my window lattice;
Let me see, then, what thereat is, and this mystery explore—
Let my heart be still a moment and this mystery explore;—
’Tis the wind and nothing more!”
Open here I flung the shutter, when, with many a flirt and flutter,
In there stepped a stately Raven of the saintly days of yore;
Not the least obeisance made he; not a minute stopped or stayed he;
But, with mien of lord or lady, perched above my chamber door—
Perched upon a bust of Pallas just above my chamber door—
Perched, and sat, and nothing more.
Then this ebony bird beguiling my sad fancy into smiling,
By the grave and stern decorum of the countenance it wore,
“Though thy crest be shorn and shaven, thou,” I said, “art sure no craven,
Ghastly grim and ancient Raven wandering from the Nightly shore—
Tell me what thy lordly name is on the Night’s Plutonian shore!”
Quoth the Raven “Nevermore.”
Much I marvelled this ungainly fowl to hear discourse so plainly,
Though its answer little meaning—little relevancy bore;
For we cannot help agreeing that no living human being
Ever yet was blessed with seeing bird above his chamber door—
Bird or beast upon the sculptured bust above his chamber door,
With such name as “Nevermore.”
But the Raven, sitting lonely on the placid bust, spoke only
That one word, as if his soul in that one word he did outpour.
Nothing farther then he uttered—not a feather then he fluttered—
Till I scarcely more than muttered “Other friends have flown before—
On the morrow he will leave me, as my Hopes have flown before.”
Then the bird said “Nevermore.”
Startled at the stillness broken by reply so aptly spoken,
“Doubtless,” said I, “what it utters is its only stock and store
Caught from some unhappy master whom unmerciful Disaster
Followed fast and followed faster till his songs one burden bore—
Till the dirges of his Hope that melancholy burden bore
Of ‘Never—nevermore’.”
But the Raven still beguiling all my fancy into smiling,
Straight I wheeled a cushioned seat in front of bird, and bust and door;
Then, upon the velvet sinking, I betook myself to linking
Fancy unto fancy, thinking what this ominous bird of yore—
What this grim, ungainly, ghastly, gaunt, and ominous bird of yore
Meant in croaking “Nevermore.”
This I sat engaged in guessing, but no syllable expressing
To the fowl whose fiery eyes now burned into my bosom’s core;
This and more I sat divining, with my head at ease reclining
On the cushion’s velvet lining that the lamp-light gloated o’er,
But whose velvet-violet lining with the lamp-light gloating o’er,
She shall press, ah, nevermore!
Then, methought, the air grew denser, perfumed from an unseen censer
Swung by Seraphim whose foot-falls tinkled on the tufted floor.
“Wretch,” I cried, “thy God hath lent thee—by these angels he hath sent thee
Respite—respite and nepenthe from thy memories of Lenore;
Quaff, oh quaff this kind nepenthe and forget this lost Lenore!”
Quoth the Raven “Nevermore.”
“Prophet!” said I, “thing of evil!—prophet still, if bird or devil!—
Whether Tempter sent, or whether tempest tossed thee here ashore,
Desolate yet all undaunted, on this desert land enchanted—
On this home by Horror haunted—tell me truly, I implore—
Is there—is there balm in Gilead?—tell me—tell me, I implore!”
Quoth the Raven “Nevermore.”
“Prophet!” said I, “thing of evil!—prophet still, if bird or devil!
By that Heaven that bends above us—by that God we both adore—
Tell this soul with sorrow laden if, within the distant Aidenn,
It shall clasp a sainted maiden whom the angels name Lenore—
Clasp a rare and radiant maiden whom the angels name Lenore.”
Quoth the Raven “Nevermore.”
“Be that word our sign of parting, bird or fiend!” I shrieked, upstarting—
“Get thee back into the tempest and the Night’s Plutonian shore!
Leave no black plume as a token of that lie thy soul hath spoken!
Leave my loneliness unbroken!—quit the bust above my door!
Take thy beak from out my heart, and take thy form from off my door!”
Quoth the Raven “Nevermore.”
And the Raven, never flitting, still is sitting, still is sitting
On the pallid bust of Pallas just above my chamber door;
And his eyes have all the seeming of a demon’s that is dreaming,
And the lamp-light o’er him streaming throws his shadow on the floor;
And my soul from out that shadow that lies floating on the floor
Shall be lifted—nevermore!

Gustave Dore
And some resources here ...
Can you provide me with a close literary analysis of Poe's The Raven in the style of I. A. Richards. The audience is an Eng Lit undergraduate of the 1930s at Oxford.
Certainly! Here is a close literary analysis of *The Raven* by Edgar Allan Poe in the style of I. A. Richards, tailored for an English Literature undergraduate at Oxford in the 1930s:
**Analysis of *The Raven* by Edgar Allan Poe**

*The Raven*, a narrative poem by Edgar Allan Poe, stands as one of the most meticulously crafted works of American poetry, both in terms of form and psychological depth. Its rich symbolism, rhythmic precision, and mastery over atmosphere make it a prime subject for a formalist analysis, focusing on the text itself and its emotional impact, rather than biographical or historical context. Let us approach this poem with a close reading, closely observing the interplay of sound, diction, and imagery, as well as the psychological tension between the protagonist and the symbolic raven.
**Sound and Structure**

At the forefront of *The Raven*’s power lies its hypnotic rhythm, governed by a strict meter and rhyme scheme. The poem is composed in trochaic octameter—a rhythm that, though irregular for most English poetry, contributes significantly to the eerie, relentless quality of the narrative. The regularity of the meter, interspersed with the recurring refrain of “Nevermore,” intensifies the poem’s sense of claustrophobic inevitability. This repetition, far from being monotonous, serves as a kind of ritualistic incantation, reinforcing the protagonist's descent into madness.

Richards’ principle of "affective meanings"—how a poem’s form directly evokes emotion—can be seen clearly in the repeated “Nevermore,” which, by its position at the end of each stanza, takes on the force of an inexorable truth. The raven’s refrain mirrors the protagonist’s internal collapse, with each echo driving the speaker deeper into despair, while simultaneously amplifying the poem’s atmosphere of dread and futility. The rhythm here is a key device; its repetition functions as a relentless emotional tide, carrying the protagonist—and us—further from hope.
**Diction and Imagery**

Poe’s diction in *The Raven* is starkly formal and imbued with Gothic connotations. The poem is rife with darkness, both literal and metaphorical. Words such as "midnight dreary," "of sorrow," "Forgotten lore," and "ebony bird" contribute to an atmosphere of gloom and foreboding. The raven itself, perched upon the “bust of Pallas,” is not simply a bird but a symbol of knowledge, reason, and ultimately, futility. Pallas Athena, the goddess of wisdom, here serves as a grim emblem of the inability of reason to alleviate the soul’s suffering. The bird is a messenger, but a messenger without hope—its utterance of “Nevermore” denies any future solace.

The act of the raven perching on Pallas—an icon of wisdom—is both a defilement and an assertion. This subversion of a classical symbol is central to the poem’s commentary on the insufficiency of rational thought in confronting human grief. The raven’s coldly logical repetition of "Nevermore" suggests a universe in which reason is not a balm for sorrow, but a futile attempt to escape an inescapable truth.
**Psychological Landscape**

The speaker’s mental unraveling provides the psychological intensity that drives *The Raven*. The first-person narrative perspective places us directly inside the mind of a man who is both desperate for answers and yet terrified of the knowledge the raven offers. Poe’s exploration of grief and mourning reaches a fever pitch when we consider the speaker's obsession with his lost Lenore, the symbolic figure of idealized love. The raven, initially greeted with a mixture of curiosity and humor, soon becomes a cruel reminder that there is no hope for reunion, no comfort to be found in the world of the living.

I. A. Richards' emphasis on *"emotion-meaning"*—the idea that meaning is shaped not just by word choice but by its ability to evoke specific emotional responses—can be seen clearly here. The speaker’s shifting emotions mirror a process of mourning and madness. What begins as a rational inquiry, a plea for answers from the raven, eventually becomes a spiraling torment as the bird’s unyielding refrain drowns out any possibility of reconciliation. Each interaction with the raven deepens the speaker’s obsession and disillusionment, culminating in the poignant realization that his soul is forever trapped in the "shadow of that thought."
**Symbolism of "Nevermore"**

"Nevermore" is not simply a refrain; it is a key symbol of finality, rejection, and the absence of redemption. The word signals the impossibility of escape from the agony of loss. In this respect, it may be seen as a commentary on the human condition—one that resonates with the 1930s undergraduate sensibility grappling with the traumas of war and uncertainty. “Nevermore” reflects the crushing finality of death, the hopelessness of searching for meaning in the face of loss. There is no promise of peace, no comfort in religion, no consolation in intellectual pursuits. The raven’s presence suggests that, in the face of profound grief, the human being is left with nothing but the echo of despair.

This finality is emphasized further by the speaker’s own descent into emotional and psychological collapse. The raven’s unrelenting chorus of “Nevermore” seems to drown out the speaker’s last vestiges of reason. He questions the bird, but the answers remain the same: death has no hope, no escape, no possibility of rebirth. Through this symbolism, Poe evokes a sense of existential anguish, aligned with Richards' theories about the emotional weight of words and their ability to resonate deeply within the psyche.
**Conclusion**

In The Rave*, Poe utilizes both form and content to create an experience that is as psychologically profound as it is formally precise. The poem is an intricate dance of sound and sense, where rhythm and diction serve not merely as structural components but as extensions of the speaker’s emotional state. By focusing on the text itself, we witness the unraveling of a man consumed by grief, unable to escape the oppressive weight of loss, reason, and despair. For the 1930s Oxford undergraduate, *Te Raven*is not just an exploration of Gothic tropes, but a poignant reflection on the limits of human existence and the harsh, inescapable reality of death—a meditation made all the more powerful through Poe's masterful use of sound, imagery, and psychological insight.

This style of analysis, influenced by I.A. Richards’ formalist approach, is grounded in a careful reading of the poem’s language and structure, emphasizing the psychological dimensions of the text. The tone should resonate with an audience familiar with the 1930s literary tradition at Oxford, focusing on the emotional and formal qualities that define the poem’s impact.
